pullRequest.body:
Generalize `instIsDomainCoordinateRing` from normalized GCD domains to all domains, by reducing to the field case via the injective ring hom to the field of fractions. (This works basically because the coordinate ring is a free module over the base ring and therefore flat.) To get this done, we move various declarations (some instances and `basis` API) up, and introduce `CoordinateRing.map/map_mk/map_smul/map_injective`.

---

(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:

- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

nodes.body:
### PR summary [11337ab3cd](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/12883/commits/11337ab3cd6704b5b2df4b03b6c35d17ffd89919)

#### Import changes

No significant changes to the import graph

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ instance : Algebra R W.CoordinateRing`
`+ instance : Algebra R[X] W.CoordinateRing`
`+ instance : IsScalarTower R R[X] W.CoordinateRing`
`+ instance [IsDomain R] : IsDomain W.CoordinateRing`
`+ instance [Subsingleton R] : Subsingleton W.CoordinateRing`
`+ map`
`+ map_injective`
`+ map_mk`
`+ map_smul`
`- instAlgebraCoordinateRing`
`- instAlgebraCoordinateRing'`
`- instIsDomainCoordinateRing`
`- instIsDomainCoordinateRing_of_Field`
`- instIsScalarTowerCoordinateRing`
`- instSubsingletonCoordinateRing`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/no_lost_declarations.sh short <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/no_lost_declarations.sh <optional_commit>
```
</details>

</details>

Sorry I have no idea what I just did with the other branch. I just moved a few things around according to what I said above, hopefully you don't mind. Let's merge this small standalone PR before moving on to your other PRs.

maintainer merge

(this is actually mostly understandable to me even though I don't know the first thing about elliptic curves)
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by YaelDillies.

Thanks! 
@Multramate Please remember to delete the branch https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/tree/CoordinateRing_IsDomain_branch if it's no longer used.

Thanks!

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9551011773/job/26324363000)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9551011773/job/26324362682)
Some stylistic suggestions
LGTM otherwise
~~Looks good, but why did the instances go nameless?~~ All good

Why not put this right before `map_equation` along with the other `map`-related lemmas?
```suggestion
lemma map_polynomial : (W.map Ï†).toAffine.polynomial = W.polynomial.map (mapRingHom Ï†) := by
  simp [polynomial]
```
I guess you can add `map_polynomialX` and `map_polynomialY` too. Not sure how much `map_equation` (and `map_nonsingular`) can be simplified with the new lemma(s).

I think since `WeierstrassCurve.Affine` is just an abbrev of `WeierstrassCurve`, it's not defeq abuse even if we don't insert `toAffine`. I think you introduced the abbrev just to be able to use dot notation? (Because there's no syntax in Lean 4 that allows using dot notation inside a sub-namespace.)

Of course if e.g. both `Affine` and `Jacobian` namespaces are open, then Lean could get confused which `polynomial` you are referring to, but in that case I still think both `(W.map Ï†).toAffine.polynomial` and `Affine.polynomial (W.map Ï†)` are acceptable solutions.

I introduced the `abbrev` mostly to avoid the clashes for `Affine`/`Projective`/`Jacobian`, and I think both are fine. My comment here is just for the relocation of the lemma (and for the consistency).

I think the following section organisation is better. Move the entire `Algebra` section "The coordinate ring as an `R[X]`-algebra" (from `instAlgebraCoordinateRing` to `smul_basis_mul_Y`) to right before the `Ring` section "Ideals in the coordinate ring over a ring". This won't literally compile because of misplaced definitions, but the following changes should make it work: (1) move `quotientXYIdealEquiv` from the `Algebra` section to right after `XYIdeal_add_eq` in the `Ring` section because it needs the definition of `XYIdeal`; (2) move `mk` from the `Ring` section to right before `basis` in the `Algebra` section because some of the lemmas for `basis` require this definition.

This probably doesn't need a section, unless you intend to make this a lot bigger. In which case I suggest capitalising it (like the other sections) and putting it outside the parent `Ring`/`Algebra` section.
For consistency with the `map`s in `Affine.lean`, make this `variable {A : Type v} [CommRing A] (Ï† : R â†’+* A)` with a new universe `v` added at the top of the file.

I think the name `A` was introduced back when there's only`baseChange` (with an algebra) but no `map`. Isn't S more appropriate for the target of an arbitrary ring hom?

At some point we should change `f` to be in an arbitrary RingHomClass. I did so in the EllDivSeq PR (want to work with MvPolynomial.aeval which is AlgHom and don't want to use .toRingHom), but I probably won't change the elliptic curve API anytime soon.

Also, I don't see the point of introducing explicit universe variables in this PR ...

Fair enough. Maybe you can change the few `A`s in `Affine.lean` to be `S`s if it's not too much effort. We'll make the change to `RingHomClass` in a future PR.

Regarding universe variables: what is the default if it's not explicit? I always make the effort to give them different universe variables whenever necessary to be as general as possible.
`Type*` would assign a new free universe variable, I think the default names are`u_1` `u_2` etc.
I think that `have` in Lean 4 is `haveI` in Lean 3? Meanwhile `haveI` in Lean 4 inlines this, but that's not needed.
Yeah, this is my bad habit, but probably harmless ...

Probably don't need to protect this? In any case it looks a bit crowded, and as per conventions I think everything after `by` should be in the next line.
```suggestion
lemma map_smul {x : R[X]} {y : W.CoordinateRing} : map W Ï† (x â€¢ y) = x.map Ï† â€¢ map W Ï† y := by
  rw [smul, _root_.map_mul, map_mk, smul, map_C]
  rfl
```
[map_smul](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/GroupTheory/GroupAction/Hom.html#map_smul) is in root namespace so it's certainly reasonable to protect, no?
Sure, this is mostly for the crowded line.

Everywhere I just do `Function.Injective` since it doesn't eat an extra line:
```suggestion
lemma map_injective (hf : Function.Injective Ï†) : Function.Injective <| map W Ï† :=
```

Why is this better than
```suggestion
variable {W}

lemma smul (x : R[X]) (y : W.CoordinateRing) : x â€¢ y = mk W (C x) * y :=
  (algebraMap_smul W.CoordinateRing x y).symm
#align weierstrass_curve.coordinate_ring.smul WeierstrassCurve.Affine.CoordinateRing.smul

lemma smul_basis_eq_zero {p q : R[X]} (hpq : p â€¢ (1 : W.CoordinateRing) + q â€¢ mk W Y = 0) :
    p = 0 âˆ§ q = 0 := by
  have h := Fintype.linearIndependent_iff.mp (CoordinateRing.basis W).linearIndependent ![p, q]
  erw [Fin.sum_univ_succ, basis_zero, Fin.sum_univ_one, basis_one] at h
  exact âŸ¨h hpq 0, h hpq 1âŸ©
#align weierstrass_curve.coordinate_ring.smul_basis_eq_zero WeierstrassCurve.Affine.CoordinateRing.smul_basis_eq_zero

lemma exists_smul_basis_eq (x : W.CoordinateRing) :
    âˆƒ p q : R[X], p â€¢ (1 : W.CoordinateRing) + q â€¢ mk W Y = x := by
  have h := (CoordinateRing.basis W).sum_equivFun x
  erw [Fin.sum_univ_succ, Fin.sum_univ_one, basis_zero, basis_one] at h
  exact âŸ¨_, _, hâŸ©
#align weierstrass_curve.coordinate_ring.exists_smul_basis_eq WeierstrassCurve.Affine.CoordinateRing.exists_smul_basis_eq

variable (W)
```
?

I would much prefer finer control on the explicit/implicitness of the variables. When I move things around they sometimes get accidentally introduced/hidden without me noticing. Sometimes this doesn't affect the lemmas in the same file that use that specific lemma (e.g. they're just `rw`s without specifying the arguments), but affects downstream files (e.g. they're `exact`s supplying all the arguments). When I inevitably split this file in the future to match the Jacobian split I don't want to get confused myself.
I see, this is a good cause!
Same here: why this change?
I guess this one preserves the total number of lines :)

According to the naming convention, this should be `WeierstrassCurve.Affine.CoordinateRing.insSubsingleton`, so
```suggestion
instance instSubsingleton [Subsingleton R] : Subsingleton W.CoordinateRing :=
```

I confirm that this is exactly the auto-generated name. The full list of names are:
WeierstrassCurve.Affine.CoordinateRing.instAlgebra
WeierstrassCurve.Affine.CoordinateRing.instAlgebraPolynomial
WeierstrassCurve.Affine.CoordinateRing.instIsScalarTowerPolynomial
WeierstrassCurve.Affine.CoordinateRing.instSubsingleton
WeierstrassCurve.Affine.CoordinateRing.instIsDomain

I don't think there is a style convention that we should manually name instances? Now that the instance name generation actually produces sensible names, I do feel that we should let it do its job whenever possible.
Oh sorry, I thought the autogenerated name now was something like `Blah.instSubsingleton_mathlib`

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(EllipticCurve): a coordinate ring over a domain is a domain
